results.title: Shelter Access Analysis
results.description:
Starting map for an analysis of people who live in high risk zones for lava flow on the island of Hawaii. The analysis considers the locations of emergency shelters, how long it takes to drive to a shelter, and where people live on the island.

This web application is part of the project Analyze Volcano Shelter Access in Hawaii on the Learn ArcGIS website.
tags: Analyze Volcano Shelter Access in Hawaii
results.snippet: Analysis map of access to emergency shelters.

results.title: Analysis quick lesson-Brady Gore
results.description:
This map shows the range of Nassella Tussock and the location of campgrounds in New Zealand.  This map can be used to determine which campgrounds should take steps to reduce interactions with Nassella Tussock in order to reduce the spread of the invasive weed.  The Create Buffers, Find Existing Locations, and Summarize Within tools can be used for this analysis.

This map and its accompanying workflow were created for instructional purposes only and should not be used as an authoritative resource.
results.snippet: This map shows the range of Nassella Tussock and the location of campgrounds in New Zealand.  This map can be used to determine which campgrounds should take steps to reduce interactions with Nassella Tussock.
results.licenseInfo:
This map was create for instructional purposes.

results.title: TB_WaterQuality
results.description: Wetlands perform a variety of water quality functions at the watershed scale, including removing and storing nutrients, metals, and carbon, along with regulating the temperature of surface water. CNHP modeled wetland water quality functions by reviewing literature on how different types of wetlands perform water quality functions, including associations between functions and wetland hydrogeomorphic attributes like landscape position, landform, and dominant water flow paths.  Supporting geospatial data layers include potential sources of pollutants, such as mines and oil and gas wells, along with state-listed Outstanding Waters, 303(d) water quality impaired waters, and Watershed Plans related to addressing nonpoint source pollution.
results.snippet: Watershed Restoration Toolbox - Water Quality Wetland Functions Map Service
results.accessInformation: Colorado Natural Heritage Program, COGCC, CDNR, WQCD, CDPHE, NRCS, USFS

results.title: Ag Baseline 2015 - 2015 Agricultural Baseline - copy
results.description:
[Metadata]  Description:  Agricultural Land Use (2015).
Source: The University of Hawaii at Hilo Spatial Data Analysis and Visualization (SDAV) Laboratory in conjunction with the Hawaii State Department of Agriculture, 2015.

The 2015 Hawaii Statewide Agricultural Land Use Baseline layer was created to provide a snapshot of contemporary commercial agricultural land use activity in Hawaii. It is based upon an assemblage of geospatial datasets, primarily high-resolution WorldView-2 satellite imagery (2011-2013) used as a base layer for digitization. Additional datasets used in this work include GIS layers (‘Agriculture and Farming’, ‘Inland Water Resources’, and ‘Cadastral and Land Descriptions’) provided by the state of Hawaii, Office of Planning Statewide GIS Program and other data provided by major land owners and managers. Digitized crop locations and boundaries were verified through a combination of on-the-ground site visits, meetings and presentations of draft layers with agricultural stakeholders and landowners, solicitations through a publicly accessible online web mapping portal, and spot-checking using Google Earth™ and other high resolution imagery sources. In addition to the satellite imagery, County Real Property Tax and Agricultural Water Use data were also used to identify commercial farm operations. Data for both real property tax assessment and agricultural water use were collected from each county thatprovided their most recent records, generally from 2014-2015. Not all properties that receive County agricultural tax assessment rates or reduced water cost for agricultural uses were mapped due to the small scale of some of their operations. These data sources were used to verify mapped commercial farms and identify operations that might have been missed using the imagery alone.The 2015 Hawaii Statewide Agricultural Land Use Baseline layer represents our best efforts to capture the scale and diversity of commercial agricultural activity in Hawaii in 2015 and should be used for informational purposes only.

For additional information, please refer to complete metadata at http://files.hawaii.gov/dbedt/op/gis/data/aglanduse_2015.pdf or contact Hawaii Statewide GIS Program, Office of Planning, State of Hawaii; PO Box 2359, Honolulu, HI 96804; (808) 587-2846; email: gis@hawaii.gov; Website: http://planning.hawaii.gov/gis.
results.snippet: Agricultural Land Use (2015)

results.title: Facility Capacity Map
results.description:
The Laboratory Facility Assessment Tool (ATLAS) is a comprehensive data gathering questionnaire developed by the USAID DELIVER PROJECT and adapted by the Cameroonian MOH and other stakeholders to assess national laboratory services and capacity throughout Cameroon. The ATLAS, a diagnostic and monitoring tool, can be used to map out the number of facilities that have clinical laboratory services in Cameroon, determine what services are available at different levels of the laboratory tiered system and assess the readiness of each Laboratory to conduct different types of tests. This tool will also serve as a baseline survey to complete the Laboratory policy strategic planning process. Both qualitative and quantitative data collected will be used to identify challenges, strengths and weaknesses of the national lab structure as well as opportunities for appropriate interventions by government and partners. The results reported here will serve as an integral part of the National Strategic Plan for laboratories and will help to monitor, improve, and ensure sustainability of laboratory services provided. 734 total laboratory facilities were surveyed using ATLAS. However, incomplete and missing responses were recorded for a number of survey items, which are noted in the results below.

Valid GPS coordinates were available for 558 facilities surveyed using ATLAS.
results.snippet: 2014 ATLAS Listing of Cameroonian Labratory Facilities
results.accessInformation: Travis Sondgerath

results.name: LDI
results.title: LDI
results.description: There are two B1 and two B2 PCAs. B1 denotes the highest biological signifiance and B2 denotes the next highest biological signifiance. These PCAs were selected based on the amount of anthropogenic disturbance, with two having very high disturbance, and the other two having very low disturbance (one in each biological diversity category).
results.snippet: Colorado National Heritage Program's Landscape Disturbance Index (LDI) and four Priority Conservation Areas (PCAs).
results.accessInformation: Julia Sullivan, Alex Stoneburner, Michelle Fink

results.title: TB_WaterQuantity
results.description: Many wetlands support clean water along with providing flood attenuation, stream flow maintenance during dry periods, surface water storage, groundwater recharge, sediment capture and retention, and streambank and shoreline stabilization. Floodplain, or riparian wetlands including beaver pond and meadow complexes may provide all of these functions. CNHP modeled likely water quantity and geomorphic functions by reviewing literature on how wetlands intercept, store, and release water and sediment in the landscape, and crosswalking these processes to wetland landscape positions, landforms, dominant water flow types, and vegetation. Supporting geospatial data layers include statewide floodplains, alluvial aquifers, decreed instream flows and lake levels, historic fire perimeters, irrigated lands, surface water diversions, and groundwater wells.
results.snippet: Water Quantity and Geomorphic Functions Map Service - Watershed Planning Toolbox
results.accessInformation: Colorado Natural Heritage Program, USGS, CDWR, CDWR, FEMA

results.name: Wildfire_Risk_PODs
results.title: Wildfire Risk PODs
results.description:
Wildfire Risk identifies areas with the greatest potential impacts from a wildfire –i.e. those areas most at risk when considering the four values layers. The Values at Risk Rating is a key component of Wildfire Risk. It is comprised of several individual risk layers including Wildland Urban Interface (housing density), Forest Assets, Riparian Assets and Drinking Water Importance Areas risk outputs. The WUI component is a key element of the composite risk since it represents where people live in the wildland and urban fringe areas that are susceptible to wildfires and damages. The four individual risk layers are weighted to derive the Values at Risk Rating layer.

The risk map is derived at a 30-meter resolution. This scale of data was chosen to be consistent with the accuracy of the primary surface fuels dataset used in the assessment. While not appropriate for site specific analysis, it is appropriate for regional, county or local planning efforts.
results.snippet: Wildfire Risk is a composite risk map created by combining the Values at Risk Rating and the Burn Probability layers.
results.accessInformation: Colorado State Forest Service

results.title: Shelter Access Analysis-Ingamells
results.description:
Starting map for an analysis of people who live in high risk zones for lava flow on the island of Hawaii. The analysis considers the locations of emergency shelters, how long it takes to drive to a shelter, and where people live on the island.

This web application is part of the project Analyze Volcano Shelter Access in Hawaii on the Learn ArcGIS website.
tags: Analyze Volcano Shelter Access in Hawaii
results.snippet: Analysis map of access to emergency shelters.
results.accessInformation: USGS, Hawaii State GIS Program

results.title: Analysis quick lesson - Sarah Viders
results.description:
This map shows the range of Nassella Tussock and the location of campgrounds in New Zealand.  This map can be used to determine which campgrounds should take steps to reduce interactions with Nassella Tussock in order to reduce the spread of the invasive weed.  The Create Buffers, Find Existing Locations, and Summarize Within tools can be used for this analysis.

This map and its accompanying workflow were created for instructional purposes only and should not be used as an authoritative resource.
results.snippet: This map shows the range of Nassella Tussock and the location of campgrounds in New Zealand.  This map can be used to determine which campgrounds should take steps to reduce interactions with Nassella Tussock.
results.licenseInfo:
This map was create for instructional purposes.

Commercial Campgrounds, Roads, and Nasella Tussock Range are provided under Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 New Zealand
Populated Places was released to public domain by Peter Scott.
Regions is based on/includes Statistics New Zealand’s data which are licensed by Statistics New Zealand for re-use under the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license.

results.name: CLP_watershedBoundary
results.title: CLP_watershedBoundary
results.description: Hydrologic Unit delineation are closed polygons that encompass all area draining toward the lowest point (called outlet or pour point) in the polygon. Because of varying sizes for the different hydrologic unit levels: some polygons do not include all areas up to the drainage divide, but all areas are included up to one or more other upstream hydrologic units. A unique hydrologic unit code is used to identify each hydrologic unit. The hydrologic unit codes start with the 2-digit Region number that contains the 4-, 6-, and 8-digit hydrologic units. Each hydrologic unit has a unique hydrologic code.
results.snippet: This dataset is intended to be used as a tool for water-resource management and planning activities, particularly for site-specific and localized studies...
results.accessInformation: USDA/NRCS - National Geospatial Center of Excellence, 02/20/2014. Downloaded by Nick Vogel, intern at The Geospatial Centroid, Colorado State University, 5/13/20

results.title: CRB_Nevada
results.description: The data for the Nevada dataset was primarily compiled from Nevada Division of Water Resources, GIS Data. Please visit https://water.nv.gov/mapping/gis/ for the source data, data disclaimers and metadata if not available in these data layer files. Much of the metadata for the files in the dataset are complete and were imported with the original file. In cases where there are discrepancies, metadata have been added where appropriate.
results.snippet: The Nevada dataset was collected as part of the Colorado River Basin Agricultural Water Governance Project through a collaboration between the Environmental Defense Fund and Colorado State University, Fort Collins, CO.
results.accessInformation: The Nevada dataset was created by Faith Sternlieb, Colorado State University, 20 December 2012.

results.name: Black_Footed_Ferret_WFL1.sd
results.title: Black Footed Ferret_WFL1
results.description: This map shows the potential habitats of Black Footed Ferret in Northeast of Colorado. The map is based on some important information, including the acres of the habitats is larger than 10,000 acres, 1 miles away from roads, and 5 miles away from cities. These habitats are covered by grassland and also the habitats of Praine Dog. The map shows that it's possible to reintroduction Black Footed Ferret to Colorado.
results.snippet: The potential habitats of Black Footed Ferret in Northeast Colorado.The highlight three areas are the top largest habits.

results.name: RG_DEM
results.title: RG_DEM
results.description:
The ASTER Digital Elevation Model (AST14DEM) product is generated using bands 3N (nadir-viewing) and 3B (backward-viewing) of an (ASTER Level 1A) (https://doi.org/10.5067/ASTER/AST_L1A.003) image acquired by the Visible and Near Infrared (VNIR) sensor. The VNIR subsystem includes two independent telescope assemblies that facilitate the generation of stereoscopic data. The band 3 stereo pair is acquired in the spectral range of 0.78 and 0.86 microns with a base-to-height ratio of 0.6 and an intersection angle of 27.7 degrees. There is a time lag of approximately one minute between the acquisition of the nadir and backward images.For a better understanding, refer to this (diagram) (https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/documents/301/ASTER_Along_Track_Imaging_Geometry.png) depicting the along-track imaging geometry of the ASTER VNIR nadir and backward-viewing sensors.

The accuracy of the new LP DAAC produced DEMs will meet or exceed accuracy specifications set for the ASTER relative DEMs by the Algorithm Theoretical Basis Document (ATBD) (https://lpdaac.usgs.gov/documents/81/AST14_ATBD.pdf). Users likely will find that the DEMs produced by the new LP DAAC system have accuracies approaching those specified in the ATBD for absolute DEMs. Validation testing has shown that DEMs produced by the new system frequently are more accurate than 25 meters root mean square error (RMSE) in xyz dimensions.
results.snippet: Mosaic of ASTER DEMs masked to the Rio Grande River Basin
results.accessInformation: NASA

This map and its accompanying workflow were created for instructional purposes only and should not be used as an authoritative resource.

results.name: CLP_highways
results.title: CLP_highways
results.description: Features in this dataset represent segments of public highways that are maintained by and under the jurisdiction of the Colorado Department of Transportation clipped to the Cache la Poudre watershed. These highways consist of Interstates, US Highways, and State Highways within the watershed. Features are represented by polyline (linear) geographic shapes. Bounding coordinates and feature counts reflect a statewide extent.
results.snippet: Used for general reference, geoprocessing, and cartography.
results.accessInformation: Colorado Department of Transportation. Clipped to the Cache la Poudre watershed by Nick Vogel, intern at The Geospatial Centroid, Colorado State University, 5/15/2020.

results.title: TB_HabitatFunctions
results.description: Wetlands are located at the interface between terrestrial and aquatic environments, and are often hotspots for a diverse array of terrestrial and aquatic wildlife and plants, including rare species. CNHP modeled rare wetland species support and overall biodiversity conservation, along with likely habitat for aquatic invertebrates, shorebirds, and waterfowl using wetland attributes including hydroperiod, vegetation, and land use. Additional CNHP suitable habitat models for boreal toad, northern leopard frog, New Mexico jumping mouse, Western Yellow-billed Cuckoo, and Southwestern Willow Flycatcher are included as supporting data layers. Geospatial data layers from outside groups and agencies include Gold Medal fish streams, barriers to fish passage, Important Bird Areas, Bird Habitat Conservation Areas, and priority watersheds for CPW Tier 1 fish species.
results.snippet: Biodiversity and Wildlife Habitat Functions - Map Service for the Watershed Planning Toolbox
results.accessInformation: Colorado Natural Heritage Program, Audubon, IWJV, NFHP, CPW

results.title: Conservation Leadership through Learning Alumni Careers Map
results.description:
This map shows CLTL alumni careers across the globe. Click on the picture icon or a point on the map to learn more about alumni careers. You can also view LinkedIn profiles by clicking on the website link in the description.


Please note that some career information may be outdated.
results.snippet: This map shows Conservation Leadership through Learning (CLTL) alumni careers across the globe. Click on the picture icon or a point on the map to learn more about alumni careers.

results.name: MajorRoads_PingreePark
results.title: MajorRoads_PingreePark
results.description: U.S. Major Roads represents interstate, U.S., and state highways and other major thoroughfares within the United States clipped to the quadrangle surrounding Pingree Park, CO.
results.snippet: U.S. Major Roads provides an invaluable reference and cartographic layer that make it easy to identify areas in other data sets. U.S. Major Roads overlays...
results.accessInformation: Colorado Department of Transportation. Clipped to the Pingree Park quadrangle by Luke Chamberlain, intern at The Geospatial Centroid, Colorado State University, 6/03/2020.
